item.title: Report E-2023090459
item.description:
Report E-2023090459

Identified by scraper @ 2023-09-20T15:12:40+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-09-06
  • City: LITTLE ROCK
  • State: AR
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal LLR experienced a UN1263 Carbocoat 8239 release from a 55-gallon metal drum. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup and containment. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 2-gallons of material released to an 8’ x 5’ area of the trailer floor due to improper loading. The damaged drum was containerized into an 85-gallon metal overpack. Absorbents utilized to clean the impacted area were collected and containerized into a 55-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.title: Report E-2023090445
item.description:
Report E-2023090445

Identified by scraper @ 2023-09-20T15:12:40+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-09-08
  • City: WILMINGTON
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS SHARED SERVICES, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On September 8, 2023, two (2) 5-gallon pails of paint (UN1263) were damaged by a skid and released approximately six (6) gallons of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Thin Line Environmental (TLE) to remediate the impacted site. TLE personnel deployed granular absorbents, absorbent pads and cleaners to the paint primer-impacted trailer interior and swept them in with hand tools. All spent absorbents, impacted pallets and absorbent pads were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum for terminal disposal. Damaged pails were patched up and over-packed into one (1) 55-gallon drum.

  • Description: AT THE UPS FACILITY IN MIAMI, FLORIDA, CARGO WAS BEING INSPECTED FOR AIR MOVEMENT TO NICARAGUA. ONE BOX WAS FOUND TO HAVE SIGNS OF MARKS AND LABELS HAVING PREVIOUSLY BEEN CUT OFF THE PACKAGE. INNER CONTENT INSPECTION REVEALED LITHIUM BATTERY PACKS FOR HP LAPTOPS INSIDE THE BOX.

item.description:

Identified by scraper @ 2023-09-19T15:12:14+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-09-15
  • City: BLYTHE
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal UBY experienced a UN1993 Unisol Liquid Red BK-50 release from a 330-gallon metal tote. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup and secure the tote. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 0.5-ounces of material released to the tote lid due to a loose cap. The released product was wiped up using simple green and absorbent rags. The cap was re-secured, and a slosh test was conducted to ensure there would no longer be a release in transit. The waste rags were then containerized into a 5-gallon poly pail. All waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal UBY experienced a NA1993 EC5627A release from a 330-gallon metal tote. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup and securement of the tote. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 2-ounces of material released to the tote body down all four sides and a 4” x 4” area of the dock floor due to a loose gasket. The released product was wiped up using simple green and absorbent rags. The gasket was re-secured, and a slosh test was conducted to ensure there would no longer be a release in transit. The waste rags were then containerized into a 5-gallon poly pail. All waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal XIN experienced a UN2929 Sulfix 9272 Scavenger release from a 330-gallon poly tote. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 5-gallons of product released to a 5’ x 5’ area of the trailer floor due to the tote being punctured by another pallet. The product was transferred from the damaged tote into a new one. The impacted trailer floor was cleaned with absorbents. The damaged tote was then cut up and containerized along with all cleanup debris into (2) 55-gallon metal drums. All waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.title: Report E-2023090346
item.description:
Report E-2023090346

Identified by scraper @ 2023-09-18T15:13:15+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-09-12
  • City: DICKSON
  • State: TN
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: LANDSTAR INWAY, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On September 12, 2023, at 1550 ET, Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) was contacted by Landstar personnel in Dickson, Tennessee regarding the release of approximately (40) gallons of Isopropyl Alcohol 70% (UN1219, 3, II). The shipment had 26 pallets of an unknown amount of boxes. Contractors were dispatched to clean up the release with absorbents and the proper PPE. Upon arrival, contractors confirmed that the release was from 26 crushed cardboard boxes all together containing (312) 16-ounce bottles. The release was due to too much weight on top of the boxes, crushing the boxes and bottles inside, and contained to a 5’x 4’ area of the trailer floor. All waste generated from addressing this release was containerized in (4) 55-gallon DF which was then taken offsite by contractors for proper disposal.

  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal XCN experienced a UN3272 Disperbyk-161 release from a 55-gallon steel drum. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 53-gallons of material released to a 58’ x 10’ area of the concrete lot below the dock and a 15’ x 8’ area of the trailer floor due to a forklift puncture. Absorbents were deployed and worked into the impacted areas and then collected into (3) 55-gallon metal drums. The damaged drum was placed into an 85-gallon poly overpack. The impacted trailer, concrete lot, and trench drain that flows to the onsite OWS were all pressure washed. All impacted water and skimmed material from the trench drain were collected and containerized into an additional 55-gallon metal drum. All waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0

  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On September 5, 2023, one (1) 30-liter container of UN3082 was damaged during transit and released approximately three (3) gallons of product to the trailer interior and surfaces beneath. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Thin Line Environmental (TLE) to remediate the impacted surfaces. TLE personnel deployed granular absorbents to the impacted surfaces of the trailer and worked them in with hand tools. TLE personnel utilized a plug and patch kit on the eight (8) gallon damaged drum of brake fluid and containerized it into one (1) 35-gallon poly drum as waste. All brake fluid-impacted material was collected and containerized in three (3) 35-gallon poly drums that stayed on-site in Cura's consolidated waste stream.

R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from SET Environmental (SET) to remediate the impacted surface. SET personnel deployed absorbents to the paint-impacted trailer and swept them in with hand tools. All spent absorbents and debris were collected and containerized into two (2) 55-gallon drums to be staged onsite for future disposal. Crews secured the scene and demobilized.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On September 6, 2023, one (1) 330-gallon tote containing UN1805 was damaged due to falling off the lift gate and released approximately eighty (80) gallons of product to the soil. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from SET Environmental (SET) to remediate the impacted site. SET personnel deployed poly sheeting around the impacted areas and patched the one (1) damaged tote. The crew returned the next day to perform a tote transfer. SET personnel conducted a gravity transfer of the remaining material from the damaged tote into one (1) new 330-gallon tote provided by on-site management. Crews deployed a neutralizing agent to the impacted area. Once neutralized, SET personnel utilized a back hoe to remove the impacted soil. The excavated area was backfilled with clean soil, graded to match pre-existing topography, and covered with erosion matting to promote vegetative growth. All impacted soil was collected and containerized into one (1) roll off and staged on-site pending waste profiling for disposal purposes. One (1) background and one (1) confirmation sample were obtained from the site, placed into laboratory approved containers, and transported under chain of custody protocol to the laboratory.

item.title: Report E-2023090195
item.description:
Report E-2023090195

Identified by scraper @ 2023-09-13T18:13:54+00:00

  • City: ORANGE
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On September 1, 2023, one (1) 5-gallon bucket of acetone was damaged during transit and released approximately five (5) gallons of product to the trailer interior and pavement beneath. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from ES&H to remediate the impacted site. Crews observed that the released material evaporated prior to their arrival and there was no recoverable material remaining in the trailer. One (1) 5-gallon bucket of product was punctured and released all its contents. No other buckets were damaged and the crew determined it was safe for the driver to continue to his destination. The terminal manager indicated they would offload the freight there and repackage as needed.

  • City: AURORA

  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On September 1, 2023, one (1) 5-gallon pail of UN1789 was crushed during transit and released approximately five (5) gallons of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Environmental Works, Inc. (EWI) to remediate the impacted site. EWI personnel deployed neutralizing, granular absorbents to the impacted trailer floor and swept them in with hand tools. All freight was wiped down and repalletized for further handling by R+L terminal personnel. All spent absorbents, cleanup debris, and the empty, damaged 5-gallon pail were collected and containerized into three (3) 55-gallon drum that was labeled and staged in the terminal's waste holding room.

  • Description: SequenceEvent: Leaking fiberboard box with no diamond labels found on unload. Box taken to HMPA staging pallet. Upon further investigation, it was discovered package was already damaged 8/21 around 2PM at 392 JAMS, Rankin County. DPR contained observation that internal content was cracked and commented: "The white paint is busted open and spill inside the box." DescribePack: All four plastic drums lost lids, resulting in a 16lb loss of hazardous material. Two nonhazardous drums also lost content. No internal partitions found. At least one drum cracked 2" across bottom. DurationRel: 2 and MitigateEffect: PPE donned, SDS consulted, and ventilation used.

item.title: Report X-2023081708
item.description:
Report X-2023081708

Identified by scraper @ 2023-09-20T15:12:40+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-08-21
  • City: FORT WORTH
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: Undeclared Shipment with no Release
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: FEDERAL EXPRESS CORPORATION
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On Aug 21st during the sort a package was found leaking on the belt. The package was not marked or labeled as dangerous goods on the outside of the package. Further investigation after opening the package found that there were twelve cans of a two part resin, six cans of part A and six cans of part B. The leaking receptacle PTM&W PT2475A was non-DG according to the safety data sheet, approximately 50ml of the product spilled out. The other six cans contained PTM&W PT2475B, which according to the safety data sheet are UN1760, Corrosive liquid n.o.s., 8, III. The package was contained in a salvage drum, and is being held at the station pending further disposition due to the undeclared element.

  • Description: On July 31st during the PM sort a package was found to be leaking. The package did not show any signs on the outside that it was a regulated dangerous good. There were no marks, labels, or documentation. Upon further investigation the package was opened and it contained Mrs. Meyers Clean Day Room Freshener, Lilac Scent, one of which had leaked An SDS was located and it shows that it is regulated as UN1170 Ethanol Solution(Ethyl Alcohol), 3, PGIII. The package was placed into a salvage drum and is being held at the station pending disposition.

  • Description: A Memphis spill agent was dispatched to heavy weight build up for a damaged haz shipment. A shipment on a wooden skid was struck by a forklift damaging one of the fiberboard boxes on the bottom row. The fiberboard box contained four metal cans all with positive closure rings and were separated with fiberboard dividers. All contents were placed into a steel salvage package and a new declaration will be obtained for movement.

  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: A Memphis spill agents was dispatched to the dangerous goods building for a leaking fiberboard package. The box contained 2 paint cans and fiberboard dividers. There was no positive closure on the paint cans. Each paint can was enclosed in a single clear plastic bag sealed via bag tie. The lids on both paint cans were slightly ajar allowing the leakage of content. Shipper will be contacted for an amended declaration for movement.

The metal can was not packaged with positive closure and had styrofoam peanuts for dunnage. It was placed into a steel salvage package and a new declaration will be obtained for movement.

  • Description: A Memphis spill agent was dispatched to the Dangerous Goods Building for a fiber board box with signs of release. The box contained 20 bottles of various sizes. The bottles were separated into 4 separate clear plastic bags sealed via bag ties. Each individual bottle was enclosed in bubble wrap and wrapped in a hazmat pad. One of the bottles was shattered and released all of its contents. The shipper was contacted for an amened declaration for movement.

  • Description: A Memphis spill agent was dispatched to the Dangerous goods building for a fiberboard box with signs of a release. The agents was told that the fiberboard box had been dropped during the unloading process. Inside of the fiberboard box were four metal jerrycans. One of the jerrycans had a damaged bottom chime causing to release it's contents inside of the fiberboard box. All contents were placed into a steel salvage package and a new declaration will be obtained for movement.

  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal XSW experienced a 5-ounce release of UN3103 NOROX SHP-75 from a 5-gallon poly pail. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup. Contractors arrived onsite and located the 5-gallon plastic jug of product. There was a small pin hole on the bottom of the jug but no evidence of a release in the vicinity. ERTS was informed there was a small release inside the trailer but that had since moved on. The crew placed the jug into a 55-gallon vented poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal LGT experienced a 0.5-gallon release of UN1789 “Blue Whale Muriatic Acid” that was released from (1) 1-gallon poly jug. The release impacted the trailer as of result of a loose cap falling off during transit. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived on site and confirmed approximately 0.5-gallons of material released from a 1-gallon poly jug impacting a 1’ x 1’ area on the trailer floor. Contractors collected the released product and damaged jug and containerized them into a 55-gallon and 5-gallon poly drums. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.description:

Identified by scraper @ 2023-09-18T15:13:15+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-08-16
  • City: PHOENIX
  • State: AZ
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal UPH experienced a 2-pint release of UN1993 “Unisol Liquid Red BK-50” that was released from a 250-gallon metal tote containing residual material. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived on site and confirmed a 2-pint release of material from a 250-gallon metal tote impacting a 2’ x 2’ area on the tote and a few drops on the trailer. Contractors collected the released product and impacted pads and damaged tote lid into a 30-gallon and 55-gallon metal drums. The tote lid was successfully replaced for shipment on. All waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.title: Report I-2023090051
item.description:
Report I-2023090051

Identified by scraper @ 2023-09-18T15:13:15+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-08-05
  • City: Newark
  • State: RI
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED AIRLINES HOLDINGS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: 1. A customer stopped FA during boarding and said her vape was hot and asked him to throw it away 2. Customer mentioned the device may have been damaged while in her bag 3. FA noticed light smoke(possibly vape?) coming from the device 4. FA asked customer to wait as throwing it away may not be safe 5. Customer had a paper towel(possibly napkin) and wrapped the vape inside 6. Customer essentially put it in the FAs hands to dispose of it 7. FA immediately took it to the forward galley and submerged it in a cup of water to contain/cool 8. FA noted the device did not feel hot when carrying it to the front 9. CSR appeared moments later and FA notified CSR 10. FA asked CSR what to do with the device 11. CSR then took the cup of water, with the vape submerged inside, off the aircraft 12. Later, the same CSR advised FA that she had given it over to her supervisor 13. FA is unsure of CSR name or CSR supervisor name 14. FA is unsure of customer ID or seat number as it occurred during boarding with many customers standing in the aisle 15. FA confirmed the device was a vape, but did not unwrap from towel or pull out of water to inspect

  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Around 6:30am, the yard personnel were in the process of transferring containers to different trailers when they noticed a tote that might have a possible leak around the valve. They prepped an empty tote in the event there was a need to transfer the material out of the tote. Once they were all prepped, they checked the valve handle to make sure it was fully in the closed position. When the outlet cap was unscrewed, the material shot out of the valve due to a missing ball valve. Over half of the material was captured in the second tote and approximately 125 gals of the material released to the asphalt around the load dock. There was no release to the environment. The yard team quickly controlled the release with berms, absorbents, and vermiculite/floor dry and proceeded to clean up the material.

THE PACKAGE WAS SCANNED INTO AN AIR CONTAINER BUT WAS NOT FLOWN.

THIS PACKAGE WAS SHIPPED FROM FLORIDA USING UPS ACCOUNT NUMBER 24390W, AMAZON MFN, 333 108TH AVE. NE, BELLEVUE WA 98004.

  • Description: SequenceEvent: Package came in with bottom closures open and an admin taped up the bottom and opened the top closures to replace the bottles inside. They were using the foam liner to lift the bottles while supporting the bottom when the foam liner failed and two of the 4L bottles fell out. They fell to the floor and shattered and released their contents. The spill and broken glass was cleaned up and placed in a HazMat tote. DescribePack: Package came with bottom closures open. Foam liner failed and glass bottles fell to the floor and shattered. DurationRel: 0 and MitigateEffect: Spill was cleaned up immediately with loose absorb.

  • Carrier/Reporter: CSX TRANSPORTATION, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0

  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: ON 08/04/23 at 07:57 AM in the area of MP QC169.9 on the Mohawk Subdivision the M36304 traveling westbound derailed multiple railcars. 9 of the railcars were residue hazardous material railcars. No release of hazardous materials or package failure occurred due to the incident. State Route 5 eastbound was closed due to the derailment and Amtrak passengers were delayed. HEPACO, a CSX response contractor, and David Scoons, a CSX Senior Manager of Hazardous Materials, responded to the incident to perform assessments of the damaged tank cars as well as ensure that no additional critical damage was sustained during removal of the residue tank cars. All cars were removed from the derailment site without incident.

item.title: Report E-2023090223
item.description:
Report E-2023090223

Identified by scraper @ 2023-09-14T15:12:04+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-08-31
  • City: JACKSONVILLE
  • State: FL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: CSX CORPORATION
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On 08-31-23 at 1321 a FRA Inspector in the CSXT Edgewood Yard discovered UTLX645049, a loaded tank car of Crude Sulfate Terpentine leaking vapors from manway. The car was isolated and Georgia-Pacific LLC was notified (CHEMTREC Report #2023083100164). Hepaco LLC, a CSXT response contractor, was dispatched to the scene and found the vapors were being released from the manway. The issue identified and corrective actions were communicated to the shipper contact Tom Davidson and 404-376-9550. Contractor personnel opened manway and found that gasket was damaged, Hepaco installed a new manway gasket and tool tightened manway safety bolts. The leak was secured and the car released for transport. This incident did not require a special switching move.

RESPONDER DETERMINED THE PACKAGE WAS LEAKING INTERNALLY AND BROUGHT THE PACKAGE TO THE DMP. IT WAS DETERMINED THE BATTERY WAS LEAKING. RESPONDER DISCOVERED THE INTERNAL PACKAGING WAS FORMED FOAM AND A PLASTIC BAG WITH A ZIP TIE. THE ACID HAD LEAKED THROUGH THE PLASTIC BAG.

  • Description: SequenceEvent: While traveling down the non-conveyable belt the package somehow ended up on its side. One bottle with the loose cap leaked but the spillage was absorbed by the box and nothing was released. The bottle that leaked was the TISAB I, which does not appear to be a hazmat. The Sulfuric Acid that is a hazmat does not appear to have leaked. DescribePack: The bottle of TISAB I had a slightly loose cap so it did not have a complete seal. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: The box absorbed the release. The box was immediately put into a hazmat bin in order to separate it from all other packages.

item.title: Report E-2023090193
item.description:
Report E-2023090193

Identified by scraper @ 2023-09-13T18:13:54+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-08-30
  • City: AMARILLO
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On August 30, 2023, one (1) 55-gallon drum of paint was punctured by a forklift and released approximately fifteen (15) gallons of product to the concrete surface. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Lone Star Hazmat (LSH) to remediate the impacted surface. LSH personnel overpacked the damaged 55-gallon drum in one (1) 85-gallon drum. The crew then deployed granular absorbents to the concrete and swept them in using hand tools. All spent absorbents and clean up debris were containerized in one (1) 55-gallon drum for disposal. The crew returned the next day to commence power washing procedures. A boom was deployed to contain the area while crews pressure washed. One hundred and fifty (150) gallons of paint-rinseate were collected into three (3) 55-gallon drums. One (1) drum of spent absorbents, boom, and cleanup debris was also generated as waste. All four (4) 55-gallon drums of waste were staged on-site for further handling by R+L personnel.

item.title: Report E-2023090187
item.description:
Report E-2023090187

Identified by scraper @ 2023-09-13T18:13:54+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-08-30
  • City: ANTIOCH
  • State: TN
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On August 30, 2023, two (2) one-gallon pails of concrete stain acid (UN1263) were punctured with a forklift and released approximately one (1) gallon of product to the loading dock floor and adjacent boxes. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Hull's Environmental Services (HES) to remediate the impacted site. The crew identified the impacted pallet, removed the damaged containers, removed the impacted boxes, and restacked the unaffected cargo. The damaged pails were collected and containerized in one (1) 55-gallon drum. HES personnel utilized absorbents, absorbent pads, and neutralizer to remediate the impacted areas. The impacted solids were collected with hand tools. All impacted boxes, absorbents, and absorbent pads were collected and containerized in two (2) 55-gallon drums. All three (3) drums were labeled and staged onsite for disposal by R+L.

item.title: Report E-2023090124
item.description:
Report E-2023090124

Identified by scraper @ 2023-09-13T18:13:54+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-08-13
  • City: Eureka
  • State: NV
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: HUNT & SONS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Driver was distracted trying to pick up spilled soda off of the floor and took his eyes off of the road when his Semi left the right side of the road. When he looked back up he realized that all wheels were off of the road and tried to correct. When his pup was coming back on the highway it rolled over on the drivers side of the pup. Driver continued to try to get control of the rig and dragged the pup for approximately 1/4 mile, spilling fuel the whole way, until the equipment came to a stop on the westbound lane. Upon inspection of the crash site the driver observed several spot fires so he grabbed his 20# extinguisher and attempted to put them out, Shortly after stopping he observed that the tank was on fire so he unhooked his main from the pup and moved the truck down the road. The pup became engulfed in flames and was a total loss as well as the 3500 gal of Diesel fuel. Since that time Hunt and Sons has put on safety meetings at all locations for "Distracted Driving" and are in the process of turning on the in-cab cameras to help coach individuals who become distracted while driving.

  • Description: On August 25, 2023, one (1) 55-pound bag of UN3378 was punctured by a forklift and released approximately ten (10) pounds of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Thin Line Environmental (TLE) to remediate the impacted surfaces. TLE personnel utilized a hand vacuum unit to collect the released product, then used absorbent pads and a degreasing cleaner to wipe down the trailer floor and the impacted freight. The freight was repalletized for further shipment. The damaged bags, collected product, and miscellaneous waste were collected and containerized into one (1) 35-gallon vented poly drum for disposal.

Ancon personnel deployed granular absorbents, absorbent pads, and utilized a pressure washer to the bioside-impacted roadway, trailer interior/exterior and freight. All spent absorbents, absorbent pads and damaged drum were collected and containerized into three (3) 55-gallon drums and one (1) 95-gallon over-pack for terminal disposal.

  • Hazmat Injuries: 0

  • Description: On 8/02/2023 an employee at Veolia's Schenectady, NY 10 day intransit facility was loading drums from a trailer into another trailer when the employee scratched the side of a 55-gallon steel drum with the drum cart while placing it in an outbound trailer. The leak occurred when the employee was moving the drums into the trailer and the employee misjudged the clearance to another drum. The 55 gallon drum containing flammable corrosive liquids was scraped with a drum cart which resulted in causing a leak from the drum. Approximately one pint of liquid leaked out of the impacted drum. Liquid was only observed on trailer right below drum and did not leak out of the vehicle. The drum was overpacked into an 85 gallon salvage drum, the spill cleaned up, and transportation to the ultimate disposal facility was continued. The liquid was cleaned up with spill pads and absorbent material. The duration of release is anticipated to be less than 1 minute as the employee immediately noticed the accident and began taking measures to contain the spill.

  • Description: An employee was offloading a trailer at Veolia's 10 day intransit facility in Richmond, CA and was staging the drums outside of the trailer prior to receiving the drums to the designated location. He was utilizing a forklift in which he was approaching 4 drums that were palletized. The employee did not realize that the pallet was not a standard size pallet and was not as deep. The forks exceeded the length of the pallet and hit the drum that was on the opposing side. The forks hit the drum roughly an inch above the bottom chime resulting in the drum getting damaged and a small pinhole leak occurred. The overall duration of the incident was a less than 10 minutes and it was determined that approximately 4 to 5 cups of material leaked out. The Veolia employees on site were able to contain the spill and place the damaged drum into a salvage drum.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On August 31, 2023, at 1252 ET, Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) was contacted by Landstar personnel in Memphis, Tennessee regarding the release of approximately (1) quart of Inhibited Methacrylic Acid-GMAA (UN2531, Methacrylic Acid, Stabilized, 8, II). Contractors were dispatched to clean up the release with absorbents and the proper PPE. Upon arrival, contractors confirmed that the release was contained to the trailer floor. All waste generated from addressing this release was containerized in (1) 55-gallon poly drum which was then taken offsite by contractors for proper disposal.

item.title: Report E-2023090057
item.description:
Report E-2023090057

Identified by scraper @ 2023-09-13T18:13:54+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-08-13
  • City: CINCINNATI
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: WORLD FUEL SERVICES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On 8/13/2023, a World Fuel Services, Inc. (WFS) tanker truck and driver were dispatched to the American Heritage vessel located at the Public Landing in downtown Cincinnati, OH for a delivery. The WFS driver arrived on site around 0830 and completed site inspection with vessel personnel, then begin the delivery. At approximately, 0900 the WFS driver saw product leaking from the truck’s pumping equipment and immediately hit the emergency shut off stopping product flow. Five gallons of No. 2 diesel fuel spilled from piping where a gasket had ruptured between the truck’s meter and pump. The spill impacted the concrete parking lot and up to a gallon of diesel impacted the Ohio River at mile marker 469.9. Both WFS and the vessel personnel took action to contained and the cleaned up the spill. The vessel deployed a boom and WFS used spill pads to contained the spill. The WFS driver notified the Cincinnati Operations Manager who then notified the HSSE Manager at 0930. Additional WFS personnel and the Operations Manager were deployed to site with spill cleaned up supplies at this time. And, HEPACO, WFS OSRO, was notified and dispatched to the site. WFS notified the NRC at 0955 of the incident. The Ohio EPA and the Hamilton EMA were notified of the spill between 1008 and 1015. By 1100 the spill had been cleaned up. The spill was cleaned up using absorbent booms, oil dry, and spills pads. Both WFS and vessel personnel cleaned up the spill and HEPACO was called off. The tanker unit was placed out of service until repairs could be completed. WFS later completed the delivery with different equipment, demobilize, and left the site.

item.description:

  • Incident Date: 2023-08-14
  • City: EAST WENATCHEE
  • State: WA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: SequenceEvent: Pkg unloaded from trailer, package handler noticed wet staining of outer pack. Sent to QA, upon retail inspection found one box with 4 one gallon jugs of Pro-Brown coil cleaner, with one leaking contents. SDS sheet placed with inner package by shipper, sheet states LTD QTY less than 1L. No limited quantity label on outer pack, greater than 1L in package. Inner package has diamond label UN3266. Leaking contents also soaked into other inner package. DescribePack: 4 one gallon jugs in fiberboard box, one gallon jug leaking from cap. Cap is not loose and will not tighten down to stop leaking. Closure failure on the jug cap, inner seal or contact. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: package trapped and taken to QA where contents inspected and stood up right so jug stopped leaking. Leaking liquid only soaked into outer pack, did not damage other packages or surroundings.

item.description:

  • Description: 1. X-2023080932 SequenceEvent: Package was inbound scan at 0435 and left under rollers in the unload. At 5 when QA arrived, they were called to inspect the package in the unload. Upon inspection package was identified to be a HazMat. The cap of the inner item was loose and allowed some of its liquid contents to spill out. Cap was tightened, package was secured in a salvage drum and held at QA to be processed post sort. DescribePack: The inner item is a 2.5-gal plastic container that had a loose cap that allowed some of its liquid contents to spill out wetting the outer package. Top corner of the package is wet and appears to be tearing/coming apart. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: As soon as QA was made aware of the damaged item, they quickly responded to identify what the issue was and how to best resolve it. When it was identified as a damaged HazMat a salvage drum and container liner were retrieved to place the package in for safe keeping until it could be processed post sort. 2. X-2023080933 SequenceEvent: Package was inbound scan at 0331 and left under rollers in the unload. At 5 when QA arrived, they were called to inspect the package in the unload. Cap was tightened, package was secured in a salvage drum and held at QA to be processed post sort. DescribePack: The inner item is a 2.5-gal plastic container that had a loose cap that allowed some of its liquid contents to spill out wetting the outer package. One side of the packaging was completely wet and ripped/torn DurationRel: 2 and MitigateEffect: As soon as QA was made aware of the damaged item, they quickly responded to identify what the issue was and how to best resolve it. When it was identified as a damaged HazMat a salvage drum and container liner were retrieved to place the package in for safe keeping until it could be processed post sort. 3. Upon inspection package was identified to be a HazMat. The cap of the inner item was loose and allowed some of its liquid contents to spill out. Cap was tightened, package was secured in a salvage drum and held at QA to be processed post sort. DescribePack: As soon as QA was made aware of the damaged item, they quickly responded to identify what the issue was and how to best resolve it. When it was identified as a damaged HazMat a salvage drum and container liner were retrieved to place the package in for safe keeping until it could be processed post sort. Top corner of the package by the FedEx label appears crushed and wet. Side of package has a wet stain and appears to be coming apart.   • Description: Package was brought to the attention of the spill cleanup specialist at our Newark, NJ Ramp location. Package was seen to have wet corners which indicated leakage from inside the package. Package contained UN 1593 DICHLOROMETHANE and consisted of 1 glass bottle packed for 4L in a fiberboard box. Dunnage was not immediately reported with package, however, packing peanuts may have dissolved when product leaked. It was reported upon inspection that the bottle inside of the box had shattered. It was not reported how damage occurred to the inner container. Package was instructed to be contained in a steel salvage package and package to be destroyed as contents were a total loss.

item.title: Report E-2023070874
item.description:
Report E-2023070874

Identified by scraper @ 2023-09-20T15:12:40+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-07-23
  • City: AVON
  • State: IN
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: CSX TRANSPORTATION, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On 07/23/2023, at 0924, CSXT personnel in the Avon Yard discovered ICCX74001, a residue Covered Hopper car last contained NA3077, Hazardous Waste Solid, N.O.S. Spent Catalyst, Class 9 PGIII, leaking from the bottom of the car. The car was isolated and shipper, Shell Canada, LTD, was notified via CHEMTREC (Report # 2023-07-23-00012). HEPACO, a CSXT emergency response contractor, was dispatched to the scene and found a slow leak from the bottom outlet flange at the bottom of the chute. The issue was identified as loose flange bolts and corrective actions were communicated to the shipper representative, Jeffery Bowes, 403-465-0547, jeffrey.bowes@shell.com with Shell Emergency Management. Contractor personnel secured the outlet flange by tightening the flange bolts tool tight and decontaminating the impacted area. The leak was secured and the car was released back into transportation. This incident did not require a special switching move. 7.1 not required.

item.title: Report I-2023080043
item.description:
Report I-2023080043

Identified by scraper @ 2023-09-14T03:11:45+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-07-10
  • City: Boston
  • State: MA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: AMERICAN AIRLINES GROUP INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On Flight 382, the passenger came into the aft galley wanting to dispose of what looked like tissue in her hand. The Flight Attendant opened the lid of the trash cart so she could throw it in. The Flight Attendant caught the sight of a light purple color. She asked the passenger about it and she mentioned it was a Vape. The Flight Attendant said,"A Vape?" and she said yes. Flight Attendant called the Captain and explained what had happened. She then tells me it was warm. Flight Attendant tells the passenger"We need to take it out of the trash cart now", which we did. Flight Attendant calls the Capt back and told him the Vape was warm and if he wants me to put it in a bucket of ice water. He instructs me to place it in the fire containment bag. Flight Attendant followed the procedures for this and placed it in a cart. The passenger and Flight Attendant walked out of the aircraft together and the Flight Attendant handed the bag to the Agent. The Flight Attendant was very grateful the passenger did not throw the item in the Iavatory trash container. Note: Overheating Vape was a Iceberry Lemon Flum Float vape.

  • Description: On 07/14/2023 at approxiamtely 1215, Dangerous Goods Administration received a call from Employee 658069 at the hub facility in Memphis, reporting an declared toxic shipment. The shipment conststed of 5 overpackaed pallets, covered in white shrinkwrap. The shrinkwrap on one of the pallets torn for an unknown reason, revealing a package that was marked "UN 3249" and labeled with a 6.1 hazard label. This overpacked pallet contained hidden dangerous goods. Dangerous Goods Administration instructed the location to hold the shipment for further investigation; however, miscommunications lead to the shipment proceeding in transmit internationally, along with the other 4 overpacked pallets. Dangerous Goods Adminstrition has instructed the team to hold the shipment for furhter investigation.

  • Description: Part of a multi piece shipment, package was offered to a spill cleanup specialist at the Memphis Hub when staining indicated package was leaking. Package was seen to be in a fibreboard box. It was reported inside the fibreboard box there were 2 plastic jugs each containing 1 L of UN1245, Methyl Isobutyl Ketone. During further investigation found a cap on one of the jugs was not tightly secured on the bottle and allowed for an estimated .125L to escape. Styrofoam peanuts were used for dunnage. There was no positive closure noted on the jugs. Contents of the package were placed in a steel salvage drum and shipper contacted for amened shipper's declaration for continued travel.

  • Description: Pkg Info ( TRK NBR=589295704649 PHY STATE=No Release TRANSPORTATION PHASE=In Transit ) Commodity Info ( UNDG NBR=UN1170 CLASS=30 PSN TEXT=ETHANOL SOLUTION PKG GRP=III )Pkg Info ( TRK NBR=589295704660 PKG TYPE=Package (box/drum/jerrican/composite) PHY STATE=No Release TRANSPORTATION PHASE=In Transit ) Commodity Info ( UNDG NBR=UN1170 CLASS=30 PSN TEXT=ETHANOL SOLUTION PKG GRP=III )Pkg Info ( TRK NBR=589295704671 PKG TYPE=Package (box/drum/jerrican/composite) PHY STATE=No Release TRANSPORTATION PHASE=In Transit ) Commodity Info ( UNDG NBR=UN1170 CLASS=30 PSN TEXT=ETHANOL SOLUTION PKG GRP=III )Pkg Info ( TRK NBR=589295704693 PKG TYPE=Package (box/drum/jerrican/composite) PHY STATE=No Release TRANSPORTATION PHASE=In Transit ) Commodity Info ( UNDG NBR=UN1170 CLASS=30 PSN TEXT=ETHANOL SOLUTION PKG GRP=III )On July 30th 6 jerricans containing UN1170, ETHANOL SOLUTION, 3, III were found to be compromised. Two of the jerricans leaked some of the liquid contained inside, and the other four only had an odor. We are unable to determine the source of the leak on the two jerricans. All were placed into salvage drums and are awaiting disposition and amended shippers declarations if necessary, from the shipper.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 3
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: As flight 663(DEN-MEM) departed DEN and after passing flight level 100, a passengers lithium batteries went into thermal runaway. The batteries exited the passengers carryon bag and shrapnel from the explosion hit a few other passengers which caused some minor burns. The flight crew extinguished and cooled the batteries and placed them in the onboard containment bag. The aircraft diverted back to DEN where the batteries were removed and first aid was administered to the passengers. Passenger had the 18650 batteries in his carryon bag and installed in a charging cradle.

  • Description: Hilco Transport Company picked up a shipment of liquid asphalt at the Associated Asphalt terminal in Inman, SC. While travelling on US Hwy 176, a boil-over of the material occurred, resulting in the release of an estimated 75 gallons of liquid asphalt to the paved road surface. The material did not impact soil and/or surface water systems or surface water bodies. The liquid asphalt was stabilized using sand, then allowed to cool. After cooling, the asphalt material was recovered and transported for recycling.

  • City: NORTHBROOK

  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED PARCEL SERVICE

  • Hazmat Injuries: 0

  • Description: PACKAGE MARKED AS UN3373 BIOLOGICAL SUBSTANCE, CATEGORY B WAS DISCOVERED LEAKING A RED SUBSTANCE AT THE UPS FACILITY IN NORTHBROOK, ILLINOIS. UPON INSPECTION THERE WAS AN UNFROZEN VASCULAR TISSUE SAMPLE THAT WAS CONTAINED IN A PLASTIC BAG NOT FULLY SEALED. THE PARTIALLY SEALED BAG WAS CONTAINED WITHIN A STYROFOAM INSULATING BOX ALONG WITH ONE ICE PACK ON THE BOTTOM. THE STYROFOAM LID WAS NOT FULLY CLOSED AND A WATERY RED LIQUID HAD LEAKED FROM THE PARTIALLY OPENED LID. THE OUTER CARTON WAS WET AND STAINED AN ORANGE-RED COLOR. THE PACKAGE WAS SHIPPED FROM VETERINARY SPECIALTY CENTER, 2501 WAUKEGAN RD, BANNOCKBURN, IL 60015 USING UPS ACCOUNT 642677, U OF I DIAGNOSTIC LAB, 20015 S LINCOLN, URBANA, IL 61802. THIS PACKAGE HAS NOT BEEN ACCEPTED FOR AIR OR TRANSPORTED IN THE AIR BY UNITED PARCEL SERVICE CO.

  • Carrier/Reporter: BNSF Railway Company
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On 2023 06 21 this HAZMAT shipment was observed leaking during deramping at that Stockton Intermodal Facility. Unit was placed in the hazpit for safekeeping until remediation was complete. Hazmat One was notified and they dispatched Patriot Environmental to inspect and remediate. Contractor arrived on property at approximately 13:00 to begin remediation. Upon exterior inspection, contractor observed a liquid, with a strong odor leaking at a rate of 4 5 drops per minute from the rear right corner of the trailer. Leaking liquid appears to be evaporating shortly after hitting the ground. Once door was opened, contractor observed a shipment of mixed freight, which included two pallets of metal drums loaded at the rear. Both pallets shifted toward the door, coming to rest against a load bar, which caused damage to four drums (two of which are leaking and identified in attached photos). It is estimated that a total of 2 quarts of product leaked from two drums. Product is identified as UN1247 // METHYL METHACRYLATE MONOMER, STABILIZED.

item.title: Report E-2023060386

  • City: TAMPA

  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: CIRCLE K
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 1
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On May 06, 2023, at 0150ET, Circle K reported 9,000-gallons of gasoline released from a 9,003-gallon tanker trailer impacting the asphalt roadway, soil, gravel and a nearby storm drain due to being involved in a multi-vehicle accident. No waterways were impacted. A utility pole was also impacted. The tanker was rear-ended causing the saddle tanks to release the product, as a result the tanker caught fire. The driver reportedly passed away and the roadway was closed. The fire department put out the fire with foam. On May 06, 2023, at 0720 ET, HEPACO arrived onsite to clean up the remaining impact and debris. HEPACO replaced the damaged power pole and flushed the impacted drain with 800-gallons of water. The soil area was excavated and boom was deployed at the drain. HEPACO collected and containerized 1,700 gallons of liquid into a vacuum truck and (2) 55-gallons metal drums of gasoline impacted rags.

item.title: Report I-2023070044
item.description:
Report I-2023070044

Identified by scraper @ 2023-09-16T00:32:33+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-05-15
  • City: LAURENS
  • State: SC
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: FREEHOLD CARTAGE INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Driver and technician were transferring drum from pallet onto trailer floor when It suddenly cracked, causing contents of drum to spill out. The liquid spilled onto concrete and trace amounts impacted storm drain. Generator responded immediately to mitigate spill and potential environmental cleanup. Pigs were placed around storm drain which prevented most of the liquid from entering storm drain which helped isolate further cleanup and liquid run off. Acid absorbent material and lime were used to soak up remaining liquid. The PPE and contents of cleanup were placed ln over pack drum and transported to TSDF as required. After Inspection grounds it was determined no liquid was visibility detected in outfall nor did It Impact round soil. Under the advisement from South Carolina Department of Health and Enviromental (SCDHEC) llme was dispensed into storm drain as added precaution. In addition, quarterly storm-water was recommended to assure no further contamination occurred.

  • City: KEENESBURG

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 1
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On 4/27/2023, at approximately 07:30, a Plains transport driver with a load of crude oil was traveling westbound on Highway 52. At the intersection of Highway 52 and WCR 65, a Weld County SD school bus pulled out into the westbound lane of travel of Highway 52 from WCR 65. The Plains transport unit collided with the front passenger side portion of the school bus. The Plains employee was injured and treated at a medical facility, and a Non-DOT D&A test was completed when medically released. No injuries to the passengers or driver of the school bus were reported from the occupants. As a result of the collision, the Plains transport released approximately 30 barrels of crude oil contained on-site. The Plains company vehicle and the Weld County SD school bus were non-drivable and had to be towed from the scene.
